audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 3, Lesson 1. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Books for Unit 2 and Unit 3.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 9 in your Unit 2 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Bats, Bats, Bats!” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 9 spread>

audio.transcription: Review Phonics Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show phonics cards 1-18>

audio.transcription: Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show High-Frequency Word Cards 1-20>

audio.transcription: Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.
Multimodal mini-lesson. Listen to the sound.
audio.notes: <Visual: Show the long a spellings (train) articulation video.> MP4 Or should this be a long a articulation video?

audio.transcription: This is the sound-spelling card for long a. The "a-i," "a-y," "a consonant e," "a-e" and "a" spellings stand for the /ā/ sound. What sound does the "a-i" spelling make in the word "train?" <pause> "/ā/." Listen as your teacher continues with more long a spellings and words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for Long a>

audio.transcription: Write each spelling several times. Say the /ā/ sound each time you write the spelling.
Blend Words: Now that we’ve learned about the long a sound, let’s blend some words using this sound and other sounds we have learned. Listen as I sound out the first two words.
audio.notes: <visual: show blend words table>

audio.transcription: /rrraaannn/, ran. /rrrāāānnn/, rain. Now read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether’. Say the word nice and loud.

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about animal partnerships. First, look at these two pictures. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. ocean <pause>, sea anemone, <pause>, clownfish <pause>, tentacles <pause>, river <pause>, crocodile <pause>, plover. Look at the crocodile and the plover in the picture. What do you think the plover is doing?
audio.notes: <visual: show vocabulary card>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about animal partnerships. The word is retreat. When you retreat, you move away from someone or something that seems dangerous or scary.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, retreat>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word witness>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “Amazing Animal Partnerships”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word retreat and witness>

audio.transcription: Do you have any wonderings or questions about animal partnerships? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 1 in your Unit 3 Student Book. The title of this story is "The Rat and the Raven.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: The Rat and the Raven. The picture shows a raven, which is a type of bird.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this story: assist. To assist is to help someone. As a teacher, I will assist you with your reading. How can you assist a friend? Tell your partner about it.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, assist.>

audio.transcription: Read the story. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story spread.>

audio.transcription: Find the word that names where Rat is sleeping.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story spread.>

audio.transcription: Why does Raven need Rat to assist, or help, him? Find the sentences that answer the question.
If the prefix re- means “again,” what does repaid mean? Why does Rat say that Raven has repaid him? Do you agree? Why or why not?
How have you assisted someone at school? What did they need help with?
You can reread this story during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.
Write to Deepen Comprehension: Write about whether you think Raven and Rat could be friends and why. <pause> Share your ideas with a partner before you write. Look back at the story for ideas.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the writing journal>

audio.transcription: Total Slides

toc.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Oral Blending and Oral Segmentation

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 3, Lesson 2. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 3.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 1 in your Unit 3 Student Book. Whisper read the story “The Rat and the Raven.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 1 spread>

slides.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Oral Blending and Oral Segmentation

audio.transcription: Listen as I say the following sounds: /s/ /ā/ /m/.
audio.notes: <visual: show Phonemic Awareness image>

audio.transcription: Repeat the sounds and blend them to make a word. /sssāāāmmm/, same.
Now listen as your teacher says the following sounds. Blend them together to make a word.
Now let's segment a word into sounds. Listen as I say a word: same
Repeat the word and tap each sound as you say it. /s/ /ā/ /m/
Now listen as your teacher says the following words. Say each word. Then say each word again as you tap each sound as you say it.

This is the sound-spelling card for long a. The "a-i," "a-y," "a consonant e," "a-e" and "a" spellings stand for the /ā/sound. What sound does the "a-i" spelling make in the word "train?" <pause> "/ā/." Listen as your teacher continues with more long a spellings and words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for Long a>

audio.transcription: Write each spelling several times. Say the /ā/ sound each time you write the spelling.
Blend Words: Now that we’ve learned about the long a sound, let’s blend some words using this sound and other sounds we have learned. Listen as I sound out the first two words.
audio.notes: <visual: show blend words table>

audio.transcription: /rrraaannn/, ran. /rrrāāānnn/, rain. Now read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether’. Say the word nice and loud.
Let's learn some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: of, he, like, little, no>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word of. Say the word with me. Of. Which sounds do you hear in of? /u/ /v/. Blend the sounds together.
Spell the word with me: o-f. The word "of" does not follow the rules. We have to pay extra attention to it to remember its spelling.
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: he, like little, no.

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about walking fish. First, look at these three pictures. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. goosefish, <pause> spine, <pause> mudskipper, <pause> tail, <pause> mud, <pause> walking catfish, <pause> fin. Look at one of the fish. How is this fish different than other fish you've seen?
audio.notes: <visual: show vocabulary card>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about walking fish. The word is relocate. To relocate means to move to a new location or place.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, relocate>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words ferocious>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “Watch Out! “Walking” Fish Coming Through”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words relocate and ferocious>

audio.transcription: Do you have any wonderings or questions about walking fish? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 2 in your Unit 3 Student Book. The title of this text is "The Odd Opossum.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: The Odd Opossum. An opossum is a marsupial—an animal that carries its babies in a pouch, like a kangaroo.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this text: display. To display means “to show.” I display my favorite book on the top of the bookshelf. What would you display at school or home? Where would you display it?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, display>

audio.transcription: Read the text. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story >

audio.transcription: Find the word that means the same as scared.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story >

audio.transcription: What body parts help the opossum survive, or live? Find the sentences that answer the question.
What does the opossum display, or show? Why does it do this?
Why does the author say opossums are “great”? What do you think?
You can reread this text during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.
Write to Deepen Comprehension: List three to five facts that you learned about opossums. <pause> Draw a picture to accompany your list.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the writing journal>

audio.transcription: Total Slides

toc.section: Build Words with Phonemic Awareness Focus
toc.title: Blending Focus

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 3, Lesson 3. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 3.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 2 in your Unit 3 Student Book. Whisper read the story “The Odd Opossum.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 2 spread>

audio.transcription: Review Phonics Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show phonics cards 1-23>

audio.transcription: Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show High-Frequency Word Cards 1-25>

audio.transcription: Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.

This is the sound-spelling card for long a. The "a-i," "a-y," "a consonant e," "a-e" and "a" spellings stand for the /ā/sound. What sound does the "a-i" spelling make in the word "train?" <pause> "/ā/." Listen as your teacher continues with more long a spellings and words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card (train) for Long a>

audio.transcription: Write each spelling several times. Say the /ā/ sound each time you write the spelling.

Blend Words: Now that we’ve learned about the long a sound, let’s blend some words using this sound and other sounds we have learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
audio.notes: <visual: show the blend words table>

audio.transcription: Let's find and circle all the words with a-i.
Now, let's put a box around all the words with a-y.

slides.section: Build Words with Phonemic Awareness Focus
slides.title: Blending Focus

audio.transcription: Blending Focus: Use your letter cards to build each word I say. Let's start by doing one together. Make the word ran. <pause> Add the letter i after a to make the long a spelling. What word did you make? rain
audio.notes: <visual: show letter cards to build the words>

audio.transcription: Listen carefully as your teacher tells you the letter or letters to change to make the next word with your letter cards.

Let's build this set of words again. This time your teacher will not tell you which letters to change. Let's try one together: Make the word ran <pause>. Now change ran to rain. Which sound is different? Which letter will be different?

Build Words Booster: Let's do some more word building. Listen carefully as your teacher tells you which word to make with your letter cards. Your teacher will check your work. Think about each sound in the word you are making. Use letter cards to spell the word.
audio.notes: <visual: show the letter cards to build the words>

audio.transcription: Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 3 in your Unit 3 Student Book. Today we are going to read some cumulative sentences. These sentences contain words with the long a and other phonics skills we have learned. Let’s whisper read one sentence at a time. When you are done, we will chorally read them together.
audio.notes: <visual: Show Cumulative Sentences, pages 12-13>

audio.transcription: Circle all the words with the long a. <pause> Turn to a partner and read the words. Your teacher will listen in.
Write a sentence using the word strange. <pause> When you are finished, read your sentence to a partner.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word strange>

audio.transcription: Write a sentence using each of these word pairs: great/cake, play/rain.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word pairsgreat/cake, play/rain>

audio.transcription: Total Slides

toc.title: Use Dictation with Phonemic Awareness Focus
Use Dictation with Phonemic Awareness Focus

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 3, Lesson 4. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 3.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 3 in your Unit 3 Student Book. Whisper read the cumulative sentences.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 3 spread>

audio.transcription: A suffix is a word part added to the end of a word. It can change the word's meaning and sometimes its part of speech, or how it is used in a sentence.
audio.notes: <visual: show the word pain and the syllable "ful">

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following word: "pain." Add the suffix "ful" to the end of "pain." What is the new word?
painful. <pause> The suffix "ful" means “full of,” therefore, painful means “full of pain.”
audio.notes: <visual: show the word pain and the syllable ful and under them, the word "painful">

audio.transcription: Now add the suffix "less" to the end of the word "pain." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the word pain and the syllable for "less">

audio.transcription: painless. <pause> The suffix "less" means “no” or “without,” therefore, painless means “without pain.”
audio.notes: <visual: show the word pain and syllable "less", and under them show the word painless>

audio.transcription: Practice adding suffixes "ful" and "less" to the following words. Then determine the meanings of the new words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the following words across the syllable: play (ful), help (ful), hope (ful), rest (less), help (less), hope (less)>

audio.transcription: This is the sound-spelling card for long a. The "a-i," "a-y," "a consonant e," "a-e" and "a" spellings stand for the /ā/sound. What sound does the "a-i" spelling make in the word "train?" <pause> "/ā/." Listen as your teacher continues with more long a spellings and words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for Long a>

audio.transcription: Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Then, read each word as your teacher taps on it.
audio.notes: <visual: show the blend words table> Note: First two words animate and are sounded out.

audio.transcription: Select two words from the list. Write a sentence for each word.
Introduce High-Frequency Words. Let's learn some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: want, put, the, what, you>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word saw. Say the word with me. Saw. The word "saw" does not follow the rules. We have to pay extra attention to it to remember its spelling.
Spell the word with me: s-a-w. The letters "aw" make the /ô/ sound in the word "saw."
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: this, to, we, with.

slides.title: Use Dictation with Phonemic Awareness Focus

audio.transcription: Listen to each word your teacher says. Write the word. If you need help, tap the sounds or use your sound boxes and counters to break up the word sound by sound. Then think about the letter that stands for each sound.
audio.notes: Note: Is there a Dictation image? If not use <visual: show Phonemic Awareness image>

audio.transcription: Let's start with these two words. Write the word stay.
Now write the word brain.

slides.title: Use Dictation with Phonemic Awareness Focus

audio.transcription: Spelling Booster: Let's write some more words. Listen to each word I say. Break apart the word sound by sound, then write the letter or spelling for each sound.
audio.notes: <visual: show spelling booster image>

audio.transcription: pay
play
rain
train
save
great

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 4 in your Unit 3 Student Book. The title of this text is "A Few Funny Fish!" Point to each word as you read the title with me: A Few Funny Fish! These are jokes. Each joke contains a question and a funny answer. Read the jokes. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and poem>

audio.transcription: Find all the words in the jokes with long a spellings and circle them. <pause> Chorally read the circled words.
Write the sentence I say. Listen carefully and focus on one word at a time.

The first sentence is: We like to play in the rain. Say the sentence with me: We like to play in the rain. Now write the sentence. Your teacher will help you segment, or break apart, each word and write a letter for each sound.
The second sentence is: He will get a great cake. Say the sentence with me: He will get a great cake. Now write the sentence. Your teacher will help you if you need it.
Let's read each sentence out loud. Check your work. Your teacher will write each sentence. Correct your spellings if necessary.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the writing journal>

audio.transcription: Total Slides
Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 3, Lesson 5. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 3.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 4 in your Unit 3 Student Book. Whisper read the story ““A Few Funny Fish!” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 4 spread>

audio.transcription: Review Phonics Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show phonics cards 1-23>

audio.transcription: Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show High-Frequency Word Cards 11-30>

audio.transcription: Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.
Let's review suffixes "ful" and "less."A suffix is a word part that may be added to the end of a word. It can change the word’s meaning and part of speech.
audio.notes: <visual: show the syllable "ful" and "less">

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following word: "hope." Add the suffix "ful" to the end of "hope." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "hope" and the syllable for "ful">

audio.transcription: hopeful. <pause> The suffix "ful" means “full of,” therefore, hopeful means “full of hope.”
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "hope" and the syllable for "ful", under them, show the word "hopeful">

audio.transcription: Now add the suffix "less" to the end of the word "hope." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the word hope and the syllable for "less">

audio.transcription: hopeless. <pause> the suffix "less" means “no” or “without,” therefore, hopeless means “without hope.”
audio.notes: <visual: show the word hope and the syllable for "less", under them, show the word "hopeless">

audio.transcription: Practice adding the suffixes "ful" or "less" to the following words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the following words across from the following syllable s: play (ful ), pain (ful ), rest (less ), help (less )>

audio.transcription: Look at these words. Let's read the words together: rain, train, pain, paint, say, day, stay, play. Now look at these two categories. This is the word rain. Read the word with me. <pause> Which category should I put rain under? <pause> Yes, rain goes in the a-i category. The ai spelling never appears at the end of a word. With your partner, continue to sort the rest of the words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the sort columns for ay and ai> <visual: show words rain, train, pain, paint, say, day, stay, play> in e-pocket chart.> Note: mix up some of the words in the pocket chart.

audio.transcription: What did you notice about the words in each group?
"A-y" and "a-i" are common spellings. You may notice the a-i or a-y spelling in many words. As we read, let's look for words with a-i and a-y.

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about chameleons. First, look at the picture. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. chameleon <pause>, leg <pause>, eye <pause>, tail <pause>, branch. Look at the chameleon in the picture. What colors do you see on the chameleon?
audio.notes: <visual: show vocabulary card>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about chameleons. The word is transparent. If something is transparent, you can see through it.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, transparent>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, deliberately>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “Nature’s Crafty Color Changers”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words, transparent and deliberately>

audio.transcription: Do you have any wonderings or questions about chameleons? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 5 in your Unit 3 Student Book. The title of this text is "What Do Geckos Need?” Point to each word as you read the title with me: What Do Geckos Need? The text is about geckos, which are a type of lizard.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this text: habitat. A habitat is the place where an animal lives. A pond is the habitat for many frogs. What is the habitat for a dog? An elephant? A whale?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, habitat>

audio.transcription: Read the text. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story>

audio.transcription: Find the word that names what a gecko has on its soft body.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story>

audio.transcription: In what habitats do geckos live? What is special about these habitats, or places? Find sentences that answer this question.
Why do geckos need to find shady places or dig burrows?
How are the needs of a gecko similar to the needs of a pet cat or dog? How are they different?
You can reread this text during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.

Write to Deepen Comprehension: Draw four boxes on a sheet of paper. <pause> Write an important fact about geckos in each box. <pause> Use these facts to write a 1-2 sentence summary of the text. Share your ideas with a partner before you write.
audio.notes: <visual: show graphic organizer on page 20>

audio.transcription: Total Slides

toc.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Delete and Add Sounds

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 3, Lesson 6. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 3.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 5 in your Unit 3 Student Book. Whisper read the text “What Do Geckos Need?” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 5 spread>

slides.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Delete and Add Sounds

audio.transcription: Listen as I say the following word: cup
audio.notes: <visual: show Phonemic Awareness image>

audio.transcription: Say the word cup without the beginning sound /k/. What's the new word? <pause> up
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.
Now let's add a sound to the beginning of a word. Listen as I say a word: in. <pause> Now, listen as I say a sound: /ch/
Add the sound /ch/ to the beginning of the word in. What's the new word? <pause> chin
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.

This is the sound-spelling card for long a. The "a-i," "a-y," "a consonant e," "a-e" and "a" spellings stand for the /ā/sound. What sound does the "a-i" spelling make in the word "train?" <pause> "/ā/." Listen as your teacher continues with more long a spellings and words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card (train) for Long a>

audio.transcription: Write each spelling several times. Say the /ā/ sound each time you write the spelling.

Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Say the sound for each letter or spelling as your teacher points to it. Blend the sounds to read the word. Now read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
audio.notes: <visual: show the blend words table> Note: First two words animate and are sounded out.

audio.transcription: Let's review some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: he, like, little, no, of, saw, this, to, we, with.>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word have. Say the word with me: "he"
Spell the word with me: h-e.
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it. Then, use the word in a sentence.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: is, like, little, no, of, saw, this, to, we, with.

Build Words Booster: Let's do some more word building. Listen carefully as your teacher tells you which word to make with your letter cards. Your teacher will check your work. Think about each sound in the word you are making. Use letter cards to spell the word.
audio.notes: <visual: show the letter cards in the e-pocket chart to build the words>

audio.transcription: Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 6 in your Unit 3 Student Book. Today we are going to read some cumulative sentences. These sentences contain words with long a spellings and other phonics skills we have learned. Let’s whisper read one sentence at a time. When you are done, we will chorally read them together.
audio.notes: <visual: Show Cumulative Sentences, pages 18-19>

audio.transcription: Circle all the words with long a spellings. <pause> Turn to a partner and read the words. Your teacher will listen in.
Write a sentence using the word change. <pause> When you are finished, read your sentence to a partner.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and the word change>

audio.transcription: Write a sentence using each of these word pairs: rain/today, break/great.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word pairs rain/today, break/great>

audio.transcription: Total Slides
Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 3, Lesson 7. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 3.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 6 in your Unit 3 Student Book. Whisper read the cumulative sentences. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 6 spread>

audio.transcription: Review Phonics Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show phonics cards 1-23>

audio.transcription: Say the sound or sounds for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound or sounds for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show High-Frequency Word Cards 11-30>

audio.transcription: Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Finally, find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.

This is the sound-spelling card for long a. The "a-i," "a-y," "a consonant e," "a-e" and "a" spellings stand for the /ā/sound. What sound does the "a-i" spelling make in the word "train?" <pause> "/ā/." Listen as your teacher continues with more long a spellings and words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card (train) for Long a>

audio.transcription: Write each spelling several times. Say the /ā/ sound each time you write the spelling.

Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
audio.notes: <visual: show the blend words table>

audio.transcription: Let's review some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: with he, like, little, no, of, saw, this, to, we>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word have. Say the word with me: "with"
Spell the word with me: w-i-t-h.
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it. Then, use the word in a sentence.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: he, like, little, no, of, saw, this, to, we.

Let's do some more work with this unit's high-frequency words. Read: Look at the high-frequency words. Read each word along with me. he, <pause> like, <pause> little, <pause> no, <pause> of, <pause> saw, <pause> this, <pause> to, <pause> we, <pause> with.
audio.notes: <visual: show "he, like, little, no, of, saw, this, to, we, with" as cards in pocket-chart pockets, add one blank pocket-row, show tray with only letters for the first word.> [intended for teacher to model the first word]

audio.transcription: Build: Now let's build a word together. Watch as your teacher spells the word.
Now use your letter cards to build all the words.
Write: Write each word. Then write a sentence using each word. For example, you can start a sentence with "I saw a______?" Read your sentences to a partner when you are done.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence frame "I saw a [blank]?" Then show "saw, he, like, little, no, of, this, to, we, with" as cards in pocket-chart pockets underneath sentence frame>

audio.transcription: Now your teacher is going to make a word with letter cards. <pause> What is the word? <pause> Spell it together. <pause> Watch as your teacher scrambles the letters. Fix the spelling.
audio.notes: <visual: epocket tray with letter cards>

audio.transcription: Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 7 in your Unit 3 Student Book. The title of this text is "Make a Gecko Home." Point to the word as you read the title with me: Make a Gecko Home. This text lists the steps in making a home for geckos. It includes a diagram and a list. Authors include diagrams to help readers understand the parts of something important to remember. Authors include lists to make it easier to remember related information.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: What do you notice or wonder about when viewing this diagram?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story>

audio.transcription: Create a list of steps for creating a home for another animal, such as a dog or hamster. <pause> Share your labeled diagram with the rest of the class.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the writing journal>

audio.transcription: Total Slides

toc.section: Build Words with Phonemic Awareness Focus
toc.title: Blending Focus

toc.section: Build Words with Phonemic Awareness Focus
toc.title: Word Awareness Focus

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 3, Lesson 8. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 3.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 7 in your Unit 3 Student Book. Whisper read the text “Make a Gecko Home.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 7 spread>

audio.transcription: A suffix is a word part added to the end of a word. It can change the word's meaning and sometimes its part of speech, or how it is used in a sentence.
audio.notes: <visual: show the word paint and the syllable for "er">

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following word: "paint." Add the suffix "-er" to the end of "paint." What is the new word?
painter. <pause> The suffix "er" can mean “a person who,” therefore, painter means “a person who paints.”
audio.notes: <visual: show the word paint and the syllable for er, and under them, the word painter>

audio.transcription: Practice adding suffix "er" to the following words: play, teach, farm, work. Then determine the meanings of the new words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the following words play, teach, farm, work, each across from the syllable "er">

audio.transcription: Practice adding suffixes "ful" and "less" to the following words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the words pain, use, and help two times each, once across from the phonics/syllable card ful and once across from the syllable less>

audio.transcription: This is the sound-spelling card for long a. The "a-i," "a-y," "a consonant e," "a-e" and "a" spellings stand for the /ā/sound. What sound does the "a-i" spelling make in the word "train?" <pause> "/ā/." Listen as your teacher continues with more long a spellings and words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for Long a>

audio.transcription: Write each spelling several times. Say the /ā/ sound each time you write the spelling.

Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
audio.notes: <visual: show the blend words table>

audio.transcription: Let's find and circle all the words with ea.
Now, let's put a box around all the words with -ful or -less.

slides.section: Build Words with Phonemic Awareness Focus
slides.title: Blending Focus

audio.transcription: Blending Focus: Use your letter cards to build each word I say. Let's start by doing one together. Make the word man. <pause> Add the letter i after a to make the long a spelling. What word did you make? main
audio.notes: <visual: show the letters to build the words in the e-pocket chart>

audio.transcription: Listen carefully as your teacher tells you the letter or letters to change to make the next word with your letter cards.

slides.section: Build Words with Phonemic Awareness Focus
slides.title: Word Awareness Focus

audio.transcription: Let's build this set of words again. This time your teacher will not tell you which letters to change. Let's try one together: Change man to main.<pause>. Which sounds are different? Which letters will be different?
audio.notes: <visual: show the letters to build the words in the e-pocket chart>

audio.transcription: Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about vernal pools. First, look at these two pictures. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. spring <pause>, vernal pool <pause>, grass <pause>, summer <pause>, wild flowers. Look at the pictures of spring and summer. What differences do you see between the pictures?
audio.notes: <visual: show vocabulary card>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about vernal pools. The word is shallow. If something is shallow, it is not very deep.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, shallow>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word vibrant>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “Vernal Pools—Short-Lived Springtime Habitats”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words shallow and vibrant>

audio.transcription: Do you have any wonderings or questions about vernal pools? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 8 in your Unit 3 Student Book. The title of this story is "Rain, Rain, Go Away.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: Rain, Rain, Go Away. This is a story about enjoying a rainy day.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this story: enjoy. To enjoy means to like or have fun doing something. I enjoy reading a funny book. What kinds of books do you enjoy reading?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, enjoy>

audio.transcription: Read the story. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story.>

audio.transcription: Find the word that names the month in which the story takes place.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story.>

audio.transcription: Why do Pam and Gail have to stay home? Find the sentences that answer the question.
What activities did Pam and Gail consider doing? Which did they choose? Do you think they enjoyed their selection? Why or why not?
What do you enjoy doing on a rainy day?
You can reread this story during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.

Write to Deepen Comprehension: Draw a picture to remember the important details in the text. Label the details, such as Pam, Gail, paint, stay inside. <pause> Use the drawing to retell the story to a partner. Then, write your retelling.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the writing journal>

audio.transcription: Total Slides

toc.title: Use Dictation with Phonemic Awareness Focus

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 3, Lesson 9. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 3.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 8 in your Unit 3 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Rain, Rain, Go Away!” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 8 spread>

audio.transcription: Review Phonics Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show phonics cards 1-23>

audio.transcription: Say the sound or sounds for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound or sounds for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show High-Frequency Word Cards 11-30>

audio.transcription: Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Finally, find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.

This is the sound-spelling card for long a. The "a-i," "a-y," "a consonant e," "a-e" and "a" spellings stand for the /ā/sound. What sound does the "a-i" spelling make in the word "train?" <pause> "/ā/." Listen as your teacher continues with more long a spellings and words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for Long a>

audio.transcription: Blend Words: Let's blend some words to practice what we've learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Say the word nice and loud.
audio.notes: <visual: show the blend words table>

audio.transcription: Select two words from the list. Write a sentence for each word.

slides.title: Use Dictation with Phonemic Awareness Focus

audio.transcription: Listen to each word your teacher says. Write the word. If you need help, tap the sounds or use your sound boxes and counters to break up the word sound by sound. Then think about the letter that stands for each sound.
audio.notes: <visual: show dictation image or notebook>

audio.transcription: Let's start with these two words. Write the word gray.
Now write the word brain.
Finally, write this sentence: Did you make that great painting?

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about the hottest places on Earth. First, look at the picture. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. Dallol, Ethiopia <pause>, toxic <pause>, acid pool <pause>, rock. Look at the rock in the picture. What do you notice about it?
audio.notes: <visual: show vocabulary card>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about the hottest places on Earth. The word is inhospitable. An inhospitable place is difficult for people, animals, or plants to live in.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, inhospitable>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word exceeds>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “The Hottest Places on Earth”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words inhospitable and exceeds>

audio.transcription: Do you have any wonderings or questions about the hottest places on Earth? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 9 in your Unit 3 Student Book. The title of this text is "My Desert Blog.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: My Desert Blog. This is an online blog entry about a day in the desert.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this text: climate. Climate is a place’s usual or typical weather. The climate in Alaska is cold and snowy most of the year. What is the climate like where we live?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, climate>

audio.transcription: Read the text. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story>

audio.transcription: When did the girl and her mom go to the desert? Find the two words that answer the question.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story>

audio.transcription: What did the girl see on her hike in the desert? Find the sentences that answer the question.
What is the climate in a desert?
Would you like to go on a hike in the desert? Why or why not?
You can reread this text during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.
Write to Deepen Comprehension: Write a blog entry for the girl’s next day in the desert. <pause> Share your ideas with a partner before you write.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the writing journal>

audio.transcription: Slide Total
Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 3, Lesson 10. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 3.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 9 in your Unit 3 Student Book. Whisper read the story “My Desert Blog.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 9 spread>

audio.transcription: Listen as I say a word: may
audio.notes: <visual: show Phonemic Awareness image>

audio.transcription: Say the word may, but change the beginning sound. Change /m/, to /s/. What's the new word? <pause> say
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.
Now let's change the ending sound of a word. Listen as I say a word: send
Say the word send, but change the ending sound. Change /d/, to /t/. What's the new word? <pause> sent
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.
Now let's change the middle sound of a word. Listen as I say a word: man
Say the word man, but change the middle sound. Change /a/, to /ā/. What's the new word? <pause> main
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.
Let's review suffixes "ful," "less," and "er." A suffix is a word part added to the end of a word. It can change the word's meaning and sometimes its part of speech, or how it is used in a sentence.
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable cards for "ful" and "less" and "er">

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following word: "pain." Add the suffix "ful" to the end of "pain." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "pain" and the phonics/syllable card for "ful">

audio.transcription: painful. <pause> The suffix "-ful" means “full of,” therefore, painful means “full of pain.”
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "pain" and the phonics/syllable card for "ful", under them, show the word "painful">

audio.transcription: Now add the suffix "less" to the end of the word "pain." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "pain" and the phonics/syllable card for "less">

audio.transcription: painless. <pause> the suffix "less" means “no” or “without,” therefore, painless means “without pain.”
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "pain" and the phonics/syllable card for "less", under them, show the word "painless">

audio.transcription: Now add the suffix "er" to the end of the word "paint." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "paint" and the phonics/syllable card for "er">

audio.transcription: painter. <pause> The suffix "er" can mean “a person who,” therefore, painter means “a person who paints.”
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "paint" and the phonics/syllable card for "er", under them, show the word "painter">

audio.transcription: Practice adding the suffixes "ful," "less," or "er" to the following words and see how many new words you can make.
audio.notes: <visual: show the following words play, use, help, work, thank, rest and the phonics/syllable cards for "ful" "less" and "er">

audio.transcription: Let's make a word ladder. I will give you a clue for each word to write on the word ladder.
audio.notes: <visual: empty word ladder with 6 rungs>

audio.transcription: This word means the opposite of woman.
Change one letter in man to name something you use to cook in.
Add one letter to pan to make a word that names what you feel when you hurt your leg.
Change one letter in paint to name water falling from the sky.
Add one letter to rain to name something you can travel in.
Change one letter in train to name what you use to think.
Let's do some more work with this unit's high-frequency words. Look at the high-frequency words.
audio.notes: <visual: show "whe, like, little, no, of, saw, this, to, we, with" as cards in pocket-chart pockets, add one blank pocket-row, show tray with only letters for the first word.> [intended for teacher to model the first word]>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher reads a high-frequency word from the list. Point to the word. Read the word. Spell the the word aloud.

Now build each high-frequency word using letter cards. Then work with a partner. Take turns scrambling the letters in the words. Rebuild each word. Watch as your teacher models scrambling and rebuilding the word "little."
audio.notes: <visual: pocket chart with 3rd word spelled out with letter cards: little>

audio.transcription: Now your teacher will ask you to read and write some words to check on your progress. Congratulations on all your hard work in Unit 3!
audio.notes: <visual: show Cumulative Assessment page 30>

audio.transcription: Slide Total
